I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 

 
1. 
India for the Public–Private Partnership in Madhya Pradesh Road Sector Project. 
 
2. 
The  proposed  project  will  improve  transport  connectivity  in  Madhya  Pradesh  by 
rehabilitating and upgrading about 1,600 kilometers (km) of newly declared state highways and 
single-lane major district roads (MDRs) to two-lane widths. The project will be implemented under 
a hybrid–annuity model (HAM), which is a form of public–private partnership (PPP). This will be 
the first HAM project by the executing agency and will pave the way for increased investment in 
transport by mobilizing private sector participation.1 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
Madhya Pradesh is the second largest state in the country with an area of about 308,000 
3. 
square  km  and  is  the  fifth  most  populous  with  a  population  of  73  million.2  Agriculture  is  the 
mainstay of the state, with 72% of the population living in rural areas. From 2011 to 2018, the 
state’s economy grew by an average of 8% because of various industrial developments and policy 
measures, such as the development of industrial nodes on the Delhi–Mumbai Industrial Corridor, 
and other industrial areas and growth centers.3 Despite recent economic growth, Madhya Pradesh 
is still among the poorer states in the country with per capita income (at constant prices) at about 
63%  of  the  national  average  and  about  32%  of  the  state’s  population  living  below  the  poverty 
line.4 The state’s large size, dependence on agriculture, and distributed industrial development 
make transport infrastructure, particularly roads, a critical necessity. 
 
4. 
Road infrastructure in Madhya Pradesh. As of 2018, the state had a road network of 
about 63,637 km. About 7,806 km are national highways, 11,060 km are state highways, 22,412 
km  are  MDRs,  and  the  balance  are  other  district  roads  and  village  roads.5  The  current  road 
capacity is unable to cope with the increasing vehicle ownership with the number of registered 
vehicles growing at an average annual rate of 10.3% since 2006 to reach 11.14 million in 2016.6 
Some  areas  are  also  subject  to  frequent  flooding  during  monsoons,  which  accelerates  road 
surface deterioration, limits access to goods and services, and compromises road safety. 
 
5. 
Road sector strategy. The Government of Madhya Pradesh (GOMP), in its road sector 
master plan for 2013–2033, envisions connecting all regional and district headquarters by two-
lane roads, and connecting all villages by all-weather roads.7 This is aligned to the agenda of the 
Government of India to develop states’ road networks to enhance connectivity, road safety, and 

 

1  ADB.  2017.  Country  Operations  Business  Plan:  India,  2019–2021.  Manila.  The  project  was  listed  in  the  country 

operations business plan as Madhya Pradesh Roads Project VI but was renamed to indicate the modality. 

2  Government of India. Open Government Data Platform India (accessed 8 April 2019). 
3  The  Government  of  Madhya  Pradesh  (GOMP)  has  identified  seven  industry  growth  centers  at  Bhopal,  Gwalior, 
Indore,  Jabalpur,  Rewa,  Sagar,  and  Ujjain.  There  are  19  industrial  development  parks,  129  industrial  areas,  8 
integrated development centers, and other industrial zones being developed around these city clusters  (Sources: 
GOMP, Department of Industry Policy and Investment Promotion; and India Brand Equity Foundation). 

4  Reserve Bank of India. 2019. Handbook of Statistics on Indian States, 2018–19. Mumbai. 
5  GOMP, Public Works Department. Road Length of PWD (accessed 16 May 2018). 
6  Government of India, Ministry of Road Transport & Highways. 2018. Road Transport Year Book (2015–16). New Delhi. 
7  Madhya Pradesh Road Development Corporation (MPRDC). 2013. Development Plan for State Roads in Madhya 

Pradesh (2013–2033). Bhopal. 

 

 

 2 

quality.8 State highways and MDRs form key links between rural roads and national highways and 
are  critical  for  rural  and  peri-urban  connectivity.  Developing  this  road  network  by  increasing 
capacity and constructing all-weather roads will improve road conditions and safety and will foster 
inclusiveness by enabling better access to markets and basic services. To create a more efficient 
road network and to better link national and state highways to towns and rural areas, the GOMP 
intends to rehabilitate and upgrade these roads to two-lane roads. 
 
6. 
Previous ADB loans to the Government of Madhya Pradesh. Since 2002, the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) has provided the GOMP with five loans to develop its road network.9 
In these prior loans, about 7,300 km of roads were developed, which represents only 11% of the 
total road length in the state. Through an ADB technical assistance, the Madhya Pradesh Road 
Development Corporation (MPRDC) was established and has become a leading organization of 
its  type  in  the  country.  Previous  projects  not  only  built  the  MPRDC’s  institutional  capacity  in 
executing roads projects but have also initiated an accident response system and pilot-testing of 
an accident insurance scheme. This project extends experience from previous projects, related 
to procurement and performance-based maintenance contracts, to PPP arrangements through 
the HAM to bring private sector efficiencies for sustainable asset creation and maintenance. 
 
7. 
Use of the hybrid–annuity model. The model was introduced by the Government of India 
in 2016 to revive private sector investments in road projects since PPP participation, in the form 
of toll-based concessions, decreased from 6,144 km in 2011 to 209 km in 2018.10 The HAM is a 
mix  of  engineering,  procurement,  and  construction  (EPC)  and  build–operate–transfer  (BOT). 
Under EPC, the government pays contractors to build roads with design and implementation risks. 
Under  the  BOT  model,  private  contractors  or  concessionaires  build,  finance,  operate,  and 
maintain the road and receive fixed payments from the government during the concession period. 
For  this  project  under  HAM,  the  government  will  release  60%  of  the  total  project  cost  during 
construction, which will be paid to the concessionaire in tranches linked to completion milestones. 
The remaining 40% is arranged by the concessionaire, usually 20%–25% in the form of equity 
and the rest as commercial debt. Once the project is completed, the government will repay the 
concessionaire’s financial investment and operation and maintenance costs, in fixed semi-annual 
payments over the next 10 years. This project is designed to minimize land acquisition, and the 
use of HAM passes design, implementation, and operation and maintenance (O&M) obligations 
to the private sector, while bringing in a modicum of private sector financing. The project will be 
the MPRDC’s first HAM project. ADB is implementing two loans with HAM contracts in Rajasthan 
and Karnataka. Two of three HAM contracts of Rajasthan State Highway Investment Program are 
completed,  and  contracts  under  Karnataka  State  Highways  Improvement  III  Project  recently 
achieved financial closure.11 
 
8. 
Alignment  with  ADB’s  Strategy  2030.  The  project  is  consistent  with  the  following 
operational priorities of ADB’s Strategy 2030: (i) reducing poverty and inequality, (ii) accelerating 
progress in gender equality, (iii) tackling climate change, and (iv) promoting rural development.12 
The project is also consistent with the strategic pillar  of ADB’s country partnership strategy for 
India, 2018–2022 on providing inclusive access to infrastructure networks and services, and in 

 

8  National Institution for Transforming India Aayog. 2018. Strategy for New India @ 75. New Delhi.  
9  Prior loans are detailed in Sector Assessment (Summary): Transport (Road Transport [Nonurban]) (accessible from 

the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

10 India Brand Equity Foundation. 2018. Roads Report. New Delhi. 
11 ADB. India: Rajasthan State Highway Investment Program; and ADB. India: Karnataka State Highways Improvement 

12 ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila. 
 

III Project. 

 

 line  with  the  government’s  plan  to  revitalize  PPPs  by  strengthening  PPP  institutions  and 
promoting improved contractual modalities.13 
 
9. 

Value added by ADB assistance. ADB assistance to the project will add value by: 
(i) 

(ii) 

(iii) 

Increasing  private  sector  involvement.  The  project  seeks  to  continue  ADB’s 
engagement with the state’s road sector by assisting the MPRDC in private sector 
financing  through  its  first  HAM  project  to  leverage  government  financing  and 
improve the sustainability of capital investments. 
Developing  an  e-maintenance  asset  management  system.  The  project  will 
develop  an  e-maintenance  asset  management  system  for  state  highways  and 
MDRs, with software that can record the location, type(s) of defect, or maintenance 
required. The system will include an online module on the MPRDC’s website so 
the public can inform the MPRDC of road defects for necessary action. This system 
will enable closer monitoring of road infrastructure and timely repairs. 
Increasing public–private partnership knowledge and hybrid–annuity model 
implementation skills of the executing agency. The project will strengthen the 
institutional  capacity  of  the  MPRDC  engineers,  consultants,  and  contractors 
through training on HAM implementation, PPP investment, and project financing 
options. The gender action plan includes capacity and institutional strengthening 
of  private  partners  toward  sustained  gender  parity  in  human  resources  and 
operations to help promote and sustain institutional gender policies and practices. 

Outputs 

Impact and Outcome 

 
B. 
 
The project is aligned with the following impact: mobility and connectivity in India improved 
10. 
(footnote 8). The project will have the following outcome: road transport efficiency and safety in 
Madhya Pradesh improved.14 
 
C. 
 
11. 
Output 1: State highways upgraded to two-lane and all-weather roads. At least 750 
km of state highways will be upgraded to two-lane and all-weather standards with road safety and 
elderly, women, children, disabled-friendly features. 
 
12. 
Output  2:  Single-lane  major  district  roads  upgraded  to  two-lane  and  all-weather 
roads. At least 850 km of MDRs upgraded to two-lane and all-weather standards with road safety 
and elderly, women, children, disabled-friendly features. 
 
13. 
Output  3:  Capacity  for  hybrid–annuity  model  implementation,  and  road  asset 
maintenance and management improved. An e-maintenance system for state highways and 
MDRs will be developed. A training program to develop the MPRDC’s capacity on HAM contract 
implementation and project financing options will be conducted. 
 
D. 
 
14. 
the concession period (Table 1). 

The project is estimated to cost $904 million, including a 10-year O&M obligation during 

Summary Cost Estimates and Financing Plan

a  Includes taxes and duties of $68.89 million to be financed from government resources by cash contribution and the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB).  Such  amount  does  not  represent  an  excessive  share  of  the  project  cost.  The 
amount of taxes and duties to be financed by ADB (i) are within the reasonable threshold identified during the country 
partnership strategy preparation process, (ii) represent only 7.6% of the investment plan, and (iii) apply only to ADB-
financed expenditures. Financing of taxes and duties is considered material and relevant to the success of the project.

b  In mid-2019 prices as of March. 
c  Physical contingencies computed at 5% for civil works. Price contingencies computed at an average of 5% on local 

currency costs. 

d  Includes interest and commitment charges. Interest during construction for the ordinary capital resources loan has 
been computed at the 5-year forward London interbank offered rate (LIBOR) plus an effective contractual spread of 
0.5% and maturity premium of 0.1%. Commitment charges for the  ordinary capital resources loan are 0.15% per 
year to be charged to the undisbursed loan amount. 

Source: ADB estimates. 
 
15. 
The government has requested a regular loan of $490 million from ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources to help finance the project. The loan will have a 25-year term, including a grace period 
of 5 years; an annual interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered 
rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending  facility;  a  commitment  charge  of  0.15%  per  year;  and  such  other 
terms and conditions in the draft loan and project agreements. Based on the straight-line method, 
the average maturity is 15.25 years, and maturity premium payable to ADB is 0.10% per year.15 
 
16.  Modality. The sector lending modality is the most suitable modality for the project because 
(i) the project will finance small subprojects, i.e., state highways and MDRs throughout the state; 
(ii) Madhya Pradesh has a sector development plan in place (footnote 7); (iii) the MPRDC has the 
requisite institutional capacity to implement the sector development plan and prepare individual 
road packages; and (iv) the MPRDC has substantive experience in the procurement of contractors 
and implementation of  ADB  loans.16  The roads  selected  in this  project  are based  on (i)  sector 
development plan priorities, (ii) development priorities of the government, and (iii) readiness to 
implement.  Under  the  sector  loan,  approval  of  non-sample  subprojects  will  be  based  on 
satisfactory  technical,  economic,  social,  and  environmental  assessment  compliance,  with 
eligibility  criteria  agreed  between  the  MPRDC  and  ADB,  and  based  on  the  criteria  set  for  the 
sample roads. The selection criteria for subprojects are described in Appendix 6 of the project 
administration manual (PAM).17 The MPRDC is preparing to upgrade 800 km of newly declared 
MDRs  using the  HAM  contract model  and  has  indicated  that  it may propose  these  to  ADB  for 
additional financing in subsequent years. 
 

 

15 The government will confirm the loan tenure and repayment period.

Madhya Pradesh State Roads Sector Project II; ADB. India: Madhya Pradesh State Roads Project III; ADB. India:

Project.

 The summary financing plan is in Table 2. ADB will provide $490 million from its ordinary 
17. 
capital resources to finance part of the  civil works and consulting services during construction, 
including recurrent costs and taxes, as relevant. As the concessionaire will only be paid 60% of 
the project cost during construction, private sector investment is required to cover the remaining 
construction cost and O&M obligation. The government will provide $128 million to implement the 
project and cover annuity payments over the life of the contract. ADB funding will only cover the 
construction period. Detailed cost estimates are in the PAM (footnote 16).

18. 
costs. Details are in the climate change assessment.18 
 
E. 
 
The executing agency for the project will be the GOMP, acting through the MPRDC. The 
19. 
MPRDC was set up through ADB technical assistance, initially as a project management unit for 
ADB projects.19 The MPRDC is an empowered agency with the chief minister of Madhya Pradesh 
as the chairperson and senior government functionaries on its board. While the MPRDC is the 
implementing agency for multilateral loans, it has also pioneered a toll-based BOT approach to 
improve and maintain roads, where such tolling is feasible. 
 
20. 
The MPRDC will engage construction supervision consultants as independent engineers 
for the works contracts. Procurement, including consulting services, to be financed by ADB will 
follow  the  ADB  Procurement  Policy  (2017,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  Procurement 
Regulations  for  ADB  Borrowers  (2017,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  project  will  be 
implemented  over  4.5  years,  beginning  in  December  2019.  The  implementation  arrangements 
are summarized in Table 3 and detailed in the PAM (footnote 17).

The MPRDC will use retroactive financing and advance contracting for 
civil works and consulting services. ADB will provide retroactive financing 
for expenditures incurred before loan effectiveness but not earlier than 12 
months from the date of the legal agreements subject to a maximum 
amount equivalent to 20% of the loan amount.

arrangements agreed between the government and ADB.

Corporation, OCB = open competitive bidding, QCBS = quality- and cost-based selection, STP = simplified technical 
proposal. 
Source: ADB. 
 

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Economic and Financial 

 
A.  Technical 
 
21. 
There  are  eight  sample roads  and  about  49  non-sample roads.  The  MPRDC  prepared 
detailed  designs  that  incorporated  ADB  requirements  on  economic,  social,  and  environmental 
studies.  Engineering  designs  were  prepared  to  avoid  land  acquisition,  minimize  social  and 
environmental impacts, incorporate road safety, and mitigate identified climate change risks (e.g., 
extreme flooding). Climate adaptation includes raising embankment heights, increasing the vent 
of culverts, improving drainage, and increasing the height of bridges. 
 
B. 
 
22. 
Economic  analysis.  The  economic  assessment  used  eight  sample  roads  selected  to 
represent  the  overall  project  scope  in  terms  of  geographical  coverage,  and  social  and 
environmental safeguard issues. The analysis was conducted using the Highway Development 
and Management Model and life cycle costs that compared with- and without-project scenarios 
using  a  9%  discount  rate  and  the  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  as  decision  criteria 
following  ADB  guidelines.20  The  EIRRs  for  the  individual  sample  roads  range  from  12.6%  to 
21.8%, and their aggregation provides 17.4%, indicating that the overall project is economically 
feasible  for  implementation.  This  is  further  affirmed  by  the  sensitivity  analysis  given  adverse 
changes  in  costs  and  benefits.  The  EIRRs  remain  above  9%  in  all  cases,  individually  and 
aggregately, demonstrating the robustness of the overall project’s economic feasibility. 
 
23. 
Financial sustainability. The project will not generate revenue. HAM, contracts awarded 
under the project will include a 10-year O&M obligation. After the initial 10-year O&M period, the 
MPRDC will maintain the state highways while the Madhya Pradesh Public Works Department 
will maintain the MDRs. Both agencies have maintenance manuals in place and have historically 

 
20 ADB. 2017. Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects. Manila. 

 

 Governance 

been allocated adequate road maintenance funds. Furthermore, the project’s incremental impact 
on  the  total  state  road  network’s  maintenance  needs  is  estimated  to  be  very  small.  Further, 
assurances will be sought from the Government of India and the GOMP that adequate funds for 
annuities and maintenance will be provided. To enhance the capacity of both agencies to improve 
and maintain the assigned road network in the medium and long term, the project will finance the 
development  of  an  e-maintenance  system  for  state  highways  and MDRs  as  well  as  a  training 
program to develop the capacity of the MPRDC and contractors on HAM implementation. 
 
C. 
 
24. 
Institutional capacity. The MPRDC was incorporated in 2004 under the Companies Act 
of 1956 and is a wholly owned company of the GOMP. It is familiar with ADB procedures, having 
implemented previous ADB loans, and has strong institutional capacity for ADB and PPP projects. 
The MPRDC is headquartered in Bhopal and has divisional offices across the state. 
 
25. 
Financial  management.  Financial  management  assessment  of  the  MPRDC  was 
conducted following ADB’s financial management and due diligence guidelines.21 It covered fund 
flow  arrangements,  staffing,  budgeting,  accounting  and 
financial  reporting,  and  audit 
arrangements,  and  found  that  the  MPRDC  has  an  established  record  in  implementing  ADB 
projects  and  has  adequate  financial  management  capacity.  The  financial  management  risk  is 
moderate. The assessment noted that for ongoing ADB projects, the most recent audit reports 
were unqualified and submitted on time. However, the submission of the MPRDC’s audited entity 
financial  statements  for  fiscal  year  2018  was  delayed  by  more  than  6  months  compared  with 
previous years; this is an area that needs to be monitored in the future. 
 
26. 
As  part  of  the  project,  the  MPRDC  will  maintain  separate  books  of  accounts  following 
accounting standards acceptable to ADB. The project financial statements will be audited annually 
by  an  independent  auditor,  following  auditing  standards  acceptable  to  ADB.  The  MPRDC’s 
financial management capacity will be further enhanced by (i) making efforts to retain adequate 
finance and accounts staff until the end of the project, (ii) enhancing annual and quarterly financial 
reporting, and (iii) providing training to project staff on ADB’s procedures and requirements. 
 
Procurement. The project procurement risk is  high. The MPRDC has substantive prior 
27. 
experience with ADB procurement, including large contracts using international advertisement, 
and  with the  procurement  of  PPP  contracts  via BOT and EPC.  Contracts  for  this  project  have 
been bundled into packages to attract qualified contractors, and business opportunity seminars 
have received good responses from potential bidders. However, since private sector interest and 
financing appetite are beyond the MPRDC’s control, the risk after mitigation remains high. 
 
28. 
Anticorruption.  India’s  Prevention  of  Corruption  Act  (1988,  amended  in  2018)  was 
enacted  to  combat  corruption  in  government  agencies  and  public  sector  businesses.  ADB’s 
Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to  date)  was  explained  to  and  discussed  with  the 
Government  of  India  and  the  GOMP.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary 
measures are described in the PAM (footnote 16). 
 

21 ADB.  2005.  Financial  Management  and  Analysis  of  Projects.  Manila;  ADB.  2009.  Financial  Due  Diligence:  A 
Methodology Note. Manila; and ADB. 2015. Financial Management Technical Guidance Note: Financial Management 
Assessment. Manila. 

 

 

7 

 

 Poverty, Social, and Gender 

D. 
 
29. 
Improved connectivity  and  transport  infrastructure  will  impact  incomes,  livelihoods,  and 
jobs, resulting in multiplier socioeconomic benefits. In rural areas, improved road infrastructure 
has influenced women’s participation in gram sabhas and strengthened their participation in local 
decision-making  processes.22  Focus  group  discussions  conducted  during  the  socioeconomic 
survey  ascertained  the  inadequacy  of  the  road  infrastructure  and  safety  issues  that  restrict 
women’s  and  girls’  mobility.  Infrastructure  gaps,  such  as  the  lack  of  adequate  lighting,  bus 
shelters, and signage, were highlighted. Women were willing to participate in  job opportunities 
during construction and maintenance. 
 
30. 
Gender. The project is categorized effective gender mainstreaming. A gender action plan 
has been prepared to maximize opportunities for women’s participation and benefits from project 
activities. The project will support (i) infrastructure with  features that are friendly to the elderly, 
women, children, and people with disabilities; and bus shelters with solar lights;23 (ii) institutional 
strengthening  of  public  and  private  sector  partners  on  gender-related  aspects,  benefits,  and 
impacts  of  their  operations;  (iii)  women’s  economic  opportunities;  and  (iv)  women’s  greater 
awareness  on  road  safety  and  government  schemes  against  sexual  harassment,  exploitation, 
and  abuse  (SHEA).  The  project  will  collect  sex-disaggregated  data  on  staff,  consultants, 
contractors,  and  project-related  training.  Improved  road  infrastructure  will  provide  reliable 
transportation facilities promoting safe mobility, reduced time poverty, improved access to health 
and education services, and income-generation opportunities. 
 
31. 
HIV  and  AIDS.  Madhya  Pradesh  has  low  prevalence  and  low  risk  of  HIV  incidence. 
Contractors will carry out HIV and AIDS awareness programs for laborers at work sites, which will 
be monitored by the independent engineers during project implementation. Awareness camps for 
laborers  at  work  sites  will  include  a  component  on  SHEA  issues,  prevention,  and  mitigation. 
Executing and implementing agency staff, consultants, and contractors will also be oriented on 
this. Information related to women-centric schemes at bus stops will include information on SHEA 
and  help  line  numbers.  The  health  camps  will  educate  and  raise  awareness  of  community 
members (women, children, and adolescents) about SHEA risks, mitigation, and legal rights. 
 
Labor. The bidding documents for the civil works include provisions to (i) ensure that all 
32. 
applicable labor laws are complied with, including the prohibition against employing children in 
construction; (ii) encourage the employment of poor, affected communities, particularly women; 
and (iii) ensure that wages for men and women are equal for work of equal value. 
 
E. 
 
33. 
safeguard categories are as follows.24 
 
34. 
Environment (category B). The scope of work includes rehabilitating and upgrading state 
highways and MDRs. There is adequate right-of-way for all sample subprojects, and impacts are 
localized,  temporary,  and  can  be  easily  mitigated.  No  long-term  and  irreversible  impacts  are 

In  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (SPS)  (2009),  the  project’s 

Safeguards 

 

22 Gram sabhas comprise representation of persons included in the electoral rolls for the village council.  
23 A. Bhatt, R. Menon, and A. Khan. 2015. Women's Safety in Public Transport: A Pilot Initiative in Bhopal. Bhopal. The 
study pointed to the lack of bus shelters as one of the biggest problems of female commuters. Bus shelter guidelines 
include lighting as an important component for women’s safe mobility and public transportation usage. 

24 ADB. Safeguard Categories. 

8 

 

 anticipated. Anticipated impacts, which will mostly be confined to the construction phase, include 
elevated levels of air pollutants, noise, soil erosion, siltation of water bodies, vegetation impacts, 
occupational health and safety impacts, and impacts on the community using and living near the 
roads. Mitigation measures to address environmental impacts have been included in subproject-
specific environmental management plans (EMPs), which are included in the bidding documents. 
Consultations  have  been  conducted  with  stakeholders  and  affected  persons  during  project 
preparation,  and  their  concerns  have  been  incorporated  in  the  project  design  and  EMPs.  A 
grievance  redress  mechanism  has  been  established  to  continue  receiving  feedback  and  any 
complaints from affected parties and to address them during construction and operation. 
 
35. 
Initial environmental examinations for sample subprojects with EMPs were prepared and 
disclosed on the ADB website.25 As required for sector projects, an environmental assessment 
and  review  framework  was  prepared  to  provide  guidance  on  the  environmental  safeguard 
requirements  for  non-sample roads  that  will  be finalized  after  project  approval.  The  framework 
subscribes to both the Government of India’s environmental assessment guidelines and ADB’s 
SPS. No category A subprojects will be financed under the project. 
 
36. 
Involuntary resettlement (category B). The project is designed to avoid land acquisition 
and  involuntary  resettlement  by  improving  roads  within  the  rights-of-way  of  existing  roads. 
Stakeholders  and  affected  persons  were  consulted  during  the  preparation  of  the  sample 
subprojects, project information was disclosed, and eight resettlement plans were prepared in line 
with the acts and policies of the Government of India and ADB’s SPS. Most impacts are expected 
to be partial or temporary on shops and residential structures encroaching on the rights-of-way. 
One sample subproject will have the most significant impact, where 33 households (164 persons) 
will be significantly affected by the loss of greater than 10% of productive assets or structures.26 
As required for sector lending, a resettlement framework has been prepared to guide screening 
and  resettlement  planning  for  all  subsequent  subprojects.  If  any  changes,  additional  land 
requirements,  or  involuntary  resettlement  impacts  are  identified  during  implementation,  a 
resettlement plan will be prepared or updated for ADB approval. 
 
37. 
Indigenous peoples (category B). Social impact assessment indicated that for sample 
roads,  scheduled  tribe  households  will  experience  limited  involuntary  resettlement  impacts  on 
privately owned land and structures. The subprojects are not expected to render the scheduled 
tribe  households  vulnerable.  However,  Madhya  Pradesh  is  home  to  46  scheduled  tribes 
recognized under the constitution, and they comprise about one-fifth of the state’s total population. 
Because of the potential for non-sample roads to affect scheduled tribe communities, the project 
is  classified  B.  An  indigenous  peoples’  planning  framework  was  prepared  to  guide  impact 
screening, assessment, and mitigation of non-sample subprojects. 
 
38. 
No category A subprojects for any safeguard category will be financed under the project. 
The  Environmental  and  Social  Cell  of  the  MPRDC  will  monitor  compliance  with  all  safeguard 
requirements.  At  the  sites,  12  project  implementation  units  will  be  assigned  to  each  contract 
package to manage safeguard issues.27 The independent engineers for the construction contracts 
will  include  environmental  and  social  safeguard  experts  who  will  support  the  project 
implementation units. Semiannual monitoring reports will be disclosed on the ADB website. 

sample roads.  

 

25 Each initial environmental examination covers roads in the same geographic region and includes non-sample and 

26 Rewa–Beeda–Semariya Road–Godha Junction.

9 

 

 10 

Summary of Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan 

F. 
 
39. 
detail in the risk assessment and risk management plan.28 
 

Significant  risks  and  mitigating  measures  are  summarized  in  Table  4  and  described  in 

Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures 

Risks 
Initial delays in project 
implementation for non-
sample roads 

Limited interest by the 
construction industry and 
private sector 

Unsustainable funding for 
road maintenance works 

Mitigation Measures 
The  MPRDC  has  prepared  (i)  the  detailed  design  for  the  sample  and  non-
sample  roads  to  avoid  land  acquisition  and  (ii)  safeguard  due  diligence. 
Recruitment  for  construction  supervision  is  in  progress.  Procurement  for 
works contracts started in February 2019. However, risk after mitigation is still 
medium because of the large number of non-sample roads. 
Since the construction industry’s and private sector’s interests are beyond the 
MPRDC’s control, the risk remains high. To mitigate this risk, the MPRDC has 
bundled  all  contracts  into  packages  to  attract  qualified  contractors  and  has 
held business opportunity seminars. 
The HAM works contracts include a 10-year maintenance period, and funding 
will  be  monitored  during  this  period.  The  project  will  also  support  the 
development of an e-maintenance asset management system. 
Negative  impacts  of  extreme  weather  on  potential  countermeasures  have 
been identified in the initial environmental examinations. More detailed site-
specific risks and countermeasures will be considered in the environmental 
management plans. 

Significant road damages 
from extreme weather 
events beyond projections 
affect road use 
HAM = hybrid–annuity model, MPRDC = Madhya Pradesh Road Development Corporation. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 

IV. 

ASSURANCES 

 
40. 
The  Government  of  India,  the  GOMP,  and  the  MPRDC  have  assured  ADB  that 
implementation of the project shall conform to all applicable ADB requirements, including those 
concerning  anticorruption  measures,  safeguards,  gender,  procurement,  consulting  services, 
financial management, and disbursement as described in detail in the PAM and loan documents. 
 
The Government of India, the GOMP, and the MPRDC have agreed with ADB on certain 
41. 
covenants for the project, which are set forth in the draft loan agreement and project agreement. 
 

V. 

RECOMMENDATION 

 
42. 
I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of 
$490,000,000 to India for the Public–Private Partnership in Madhya Pradesh Road Sector Project, 
from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources,  in  regular  terms,  with  interest  to  be  determined  in 
accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; for a term 
of  25  years,  including  a  grace  period  of  5  years;  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  are 
substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan and project agreements presented 
to the Board. 
 

Takehiko Nakao 
President

Key Activities with Milestones 

1.  State highways upgraded to two-lane and all-weather roads 
1.1  Award and mobilize construction supervision consultant (independent engineer) by Q4 2019 
1.2  Award all contracts commencing from Q4 2019 and complete construction by Q4 2023 
 
2.  Single-lane major district roads upgraded to two-lane and all-weather roads

3.  Capacity for HAM implementation, and road asset maintenance and management improved

3.2  Complete road construction and start road maintenance by the concessionaire by Q1 2024 
3.3  Prepare gender parity index and disseminate findings by Q1 2024
